title: 108_s1633
content: The Act may be cited as the "Identity Theft Notification and Credit Restoration Act of 2003". It includes findings related to identity theft. Congress finds that the privacy and financial security of individuals are increasingly at risk due to the widespread collection of personal information, leading to identity theft being one of the fastest-growing crimes in the United States. Criminals use stolen personal information to open fraudulent credit card accounts and engage in other illegal activities. Identity theft is a growing concern as criminals use stolen personal information to commit financial crimes, leading to significant costs for consumers and the marketplace. In 2002, over 160,000 people reported being victims of identity theft, highlighting the need for increased protection measures. The private sector and various law enforcement agencies, credit reporting agencies, and creditors have a shared responsibility to protect consumers' personal information from identity theft. Improving customer notification, implementing fraud alerts, providing greater consumer access to credit reports, and establishing financial identity theft prevention measures can help better protect consumers. SEC. 3. TIMELY NOTIFICATION OF UNAUTHORIZED ACCESS TO PERSONAL INFORMATION. Subtitle B of title V of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act is amended to include a new section, SEC. 526, requiring notification to customers of unauthorized access to personal information. The term 'breach' in this section refers to the unauthorized acquisition of data compromising the security of personal information held by a financial institution. Personal information of a customer includes their first name or initial, last name, and other related data. The term 'personal information' for a customer of a financial institution includes the first name or initial and last name, along with sensitive data like social security number, driver's license number, credit card information, and access codes. Financial institutions are required to notify customers in case of a breach of this personal information. Financial institutions must promptly notify affected customers, consumer reporting agencies, and law enforcement in case of a breach of personal information. Financial institutions are required to notify appropriate law enforcement agencies in cases where a breach affects a large number of customers. Any entity holding personal information for a financial institution must promptly inform the institution of any breaches. Notification of breaches must be made promptly upon discovery and in accordance with regulations. Financial institutions must promptly notify law enforcement of breaches. Notification should be made promptly upon discovery, considering law enforcement needs and the scope of the breach. Notification may be delayed for law enforcement purposes if it hinders a criminal investigation, but must be made promptly once it no longer compromises the investigation. Financial institutions must promptly notify law enforcement of breaches, with notification potentially delayed if it hinders a criminal investigation. Notification to customers can be in writing or electronic form, following guidelines set forth by the Federal Trade Commission. Financial institutions must notify customers of breaches promptly, following guidelines from the Federal Trade Commission. Notification can be in writing or electronic form, including email notices or conspicuous postings. Financial institutions must notify customers of breaches promptly, following guidelines from the Federal Trade Commission, which can be in various forms such as email, website postings, media notifications, or as prescribed by the FTC. Additionally, information may be shared with consumer reporting agencies and law enforcement. Each notification to a customer under subsection (b) shall include a statement that credit reporting agencies have been notified of the breach or suspected breach, and the customer's credit report will contain a fraud alert. The customer's credit report will have a fraud alert to notify creditors of a breach or suspected breach, requiring the customer's authorization for any new credit issuance. Financial institutions must have a comprehensive information security program to comply with regulations. The financial institution must have a comprehensive information security program consistent with regulatory standards. They must notify affected customers and consumer reporting agencies of any breach or suspected breach, following internal security policies. Customers can seek damages through civil action for violations of this section. The financial institution can face civil penalties for violating this section, including damages and injunctions. Compliance with this section does not violate other laws prohibiting the disclosure of financial information. The financial institution is not in violation of laws prohibiting the disclosure of financial information unless specifically provided in this section. There is no new recordkeeping obligation imposed on financial institutions under this section. SEC. 4. INCLUSION OF FRAUD ALERTS IN CONSUMER CREDIT REPORTS. Section 605 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include a definition of fraud alerts, which notify users of a consumer's credit report that their identity may have been used fraudulently. The consumer does not authorize credit issuance unless their true identity is confirmed. The Fair Credit Reporting Act requires confirmation of a consumer's true identity before authorizing credit issuance. Consumer reporting agencies must include a fraud alert in the file upon notification by a financial institution. The Fair Credit Reporting Act mandates consumer reporting agencies to include a fraud alert in a consumer's file upon notification by a financial institution or upon the consumer's request with appropriate evidence of identity. The Fair Credit Reporting Act requires consumer reporting agencies to place a fraud alert in a consumer's file upon request with evidence of identity. Consumer reporting agencies must inform anyone accessing the consumer's credit information about the fraud alert. The Federal Trade Commission will establish regulations for removing fraud alerts. The Fair Credit Reporting Act mandates consumer reporting agencies to add a fraud alert to a consumer's file upon request. The Federal Trade Commission will set rules for the duration and removal of fraud alerts. Failure to notify users of a fraud alert in a credit report is a violation by the consumer reporting agency. Consumer reporting agencies must notify users of a fraud alert in a consumer credit report. Users of a consumer report must follow preauthorization procedures in a fraud alert and not issue credit to anyone other than the consumer. Taking adverse action based solely on a fraud alert is a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act. Consumer reporting agencies must notify users of a fraud alert in a consumer credit report. It is a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act for a user to take adverse action based solely on the inclusion of a fraud alert in a consumer's file. Access to credit reports and scores is addressed in Section 5. Section 612(c) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to provide consumers with no-cost access to credit reports and scores. Consumers can request disclosures listed under section 609 once a year and every 3 months during a 1-year period with a fraud alert. Credit reporting agencies can charge a fee for disclosures related to fraud alerts. Credit reporting agencies can charge a reasonable fee for disclosures related to fraud alerts. Section 609(a)(1) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include credit scores in the disclosures. The Federal Trade Commission must issue final regulations within 180 days of this Act's enactment, in consultation with relevant financial regulatory agencies, to implement the amendments.
